person_689.name: FrancisWilford
person_689.description: Indologist, Orientalist, member of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, and constant contributor to its journal, Asiatic Researches, for which he wrote a number of unreliable articles on ancient Hindu geography, mythography and other subjects.

person_795.name: Jupiter
person_795.description: Also known as Jove. The god of the sky and thunder, and king of the gods in ancient Roman religion and mythology.

person_860.name: Hesiod
person_860.description: An ancient Greek poet generally thought to have been active between 750 and 650 BC, around the same time as Homer. In c. 730–700 BC. he wrote a poem, called the Theogony, describing the origins and genealogies of the Greek gods.

person_324.name: RogerBacon
person_324.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

person_035.name: Homer
person_035.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

person_263.name: Pluto
person_263.description: The ruler of the underworld in ancient Greek mythology and religion.

person_801.name: Herodotus
person_801.description: Greek historian and geographer who wrote a detailed account of the Greco-Persian Wars - one the earliest existing historical texts.

person_760.name: Solon
person_760.description: Athenian statesman, lawmaker and poet, who was one of the Seven Sages of Greece, credited with laying the foundations for Athenian democracy

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_609.name: Thales
person_609.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_863.name: Anaximander
person_863.description: A philosopher who belonged to the Milesian school and learned the teachings of his master Thales. He succeeded Thales and became the second master of that school where he counted Anaximenes and, arguably, Pythagoras amongst his pupils.

person_602.name: Plutarch
person_602.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

person_657.name: Anaximenes
person_657.description: Ancient Greek Pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Anatolia. He was the last of the three philosophers of the Milesian School, after Thales and Anaximander. These three are regarded by historians as the first philosophers of the Western world.

person_1038.name: Timon
person_1038.description: of Phlius, an Ancient Greek philosopher from the Hellenistic period, who was the student of Pyrrho.

person_1039.name: DiogenesLaërtius
person_1039.description: a biographer of the Greek philosophers

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_601.name: Daimachus
person_601.description: Probably: Daimachus, Greek diplomat and writer.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_404.name: Klazomenai
place_404.description: An ancient Greek city on the coast of Ionia.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_868.name: Gos
place_868.description: Aegospotami is the ancient Greek name for a small river issuing into the Hellespont northeast of Sestos. According to Pliny and Aristotle, a meteor landed here in 467 BC after reports of a comet.

place_867.name: Thrace
place_867.description: Thrace is a geographical and historical region in Southeast Europe. Bounded by the Balkan Mountains to the north, the Aegean Sea to the south, and the Black Sea to the east, it comprises present-day southeastern Bulgaria, northeastern Greece, and the European part of Turkey, roughly the Roman Province of Thrace.
